head.title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: I.R.A. Admits Girl's Killing

hedline.hl1: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: I.R.A. Admits Girl's Killing

block.p: After decades of blaming the British Army for the shooting death of a 14-year-old Roman Catholic girl, Kathleen Feeney, in Londonderry in 1973, the Irish Republican Army publicly acknowledged that one of its members killed her during a gunfight between the groups and apologized to her family. ''Our failure to publicly admit responsibility for her death until now has only added to the pain of the Feeney family,'' the I.R.A. said in a statement to the Derry Journal.

After decades of blaming the British Army for the shooting death of a 14-year-old Roman Catholic girl, Kathleen Feeney, in Londonderry in 1973, the Irish Republican Army publicly acknowledged that one of its members killed her during a gunfight between the groups and apologized to her family. ''Our failure to publicly admit responsibility for her death until now has only added to the pain of the Feeney family,'' the I.R.A. said in a statement to the Derry Journal.
